oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aaron Douglas mural above the door, Cravath Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Douglas, Aaron
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Artists
Mural painting and decoration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A photograph of a long mural over a doorway and bookshelves, with an image of Jubilee Hall at far left, and a procession of silhouetted figures growing larger in stature, from left to right, including the profile of a graduate in mortar board and robe, as well as a woman with hand on a large globe, a male figure looking through a microscope and others. The mural is in one of the reading rooms of Cravath Hall, which formerly housed the library at Fisk University.

Aaron Douglas, born in Topeka, Kansas, in 1898, was one of the leading visual artists of the Harlem Renaissance. He was commissioned in 1930 to paint a series of murals in Cravath Hall at Fisk University. These murals depict African American contributions to American history and society. He returned to Fisk University as a professor in the late 1930s and founded the Art Department. Douglas died in Nashville in 1979.
